Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Mentoring Consortium at International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence (IJCAI) 2019

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant supports student travel for select students to participate in the Doctoral Mentoring Consortium (DMC) at the International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence (IJCAI) that will be held in Macao, China during August 10--16, 2019. This is the premier international conference for researchers in artificial intelligence research across a fully international research community. This activity will bring together a broad community of researchers in the field of AI and support junior researchers at this critical early-career stage. The DMC creates the opportunity to bring in participants who might not have attended an AI conference due to lack of resources. This is especially true for those at smaller institutions and those which have less developed AI programs. Engaging such participants has the potential to draw more talent into AI research, improve research ideas in their formative stage, and engender collaborations across the breadth of disciplines. This event provides students with invaluable exposure to outside perspectives on their work at a critical time in their research and enables them to explore their career objectives.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to support doctoral students in the USA to attend the Doctoral Consortium at the 2019 International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence (IJCAI) held in Macao during August 10–16, 2019; and interact with a selected group of doctoral students from other countries as well as senior researchers from around the world. 


Ten students were selected from US for travel awards to attend the Doctoral Consortium (DC) and other conference activities of the 2019 International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence (IJCAI). All of them presented their research at the DC and interacted with other DC participants and senior AI researchers. They interacted with an invited senior academic who presented a talk titled "What I Wish I Had Known Early in Graduate School but Didn't (and how to prepare for a good job afterward)"; and they also interacted with a career panel of senior and junior researchers and academics.

The ten supported doctoral students continue to be active in the field and most of them have published other articles since then. It is expected that they will complete their Ph.D and add to the research workforce in the field of AI.


Three of the supported doctoral students are women. It is expected that they all will finish their Ph.D in the field of AI and be role models to other students.
